[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uEVJ-KqMRO8 Video]</ref> |- |23|| [[Adam Goodes]]||{{AFL Syd}}||{{AFL Ess}}|| 2011 || 99–100 || Behind ||<ref>Marked 45 metres out almost straight in front with 13 seconds left. Details |- | Langley || [[Victorian Football League|Victorian Football Association]] || {{AFL Car}} || {{AFL NM}} || 1895 || 2.2 – 1.9<!-- Pre-1897 scoring system; behinds not counted to final score --> ||<ref>Marked on the final bell and goaled from 40yds. {{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|date=22 June 1895|publication-place=Melbourne|title=Football – the battle for the premiership|page=6|author=Observer}}</ref><ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article9365528 The Luck of Football, ''The Argus'', Monday, 8 July 1895, p.6;] [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HkwQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QZEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7155%2C3542185 The football Season, ''The Age'', (Monday, 8 July 1895), p.6.]</ref> |- | [[Jim Thoms]] || [[South Australian National Football League]] || [[West Torrens Football Club|West Torrens]] || [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] || 1945 || 33–32 ||<ref>With scores level in the Semi-final, Thoms gathered the ball and kicked a goal after the bell began ringing. The umpire hadn't signalled the end of the game so it was allowed and booked West Torrens a spot in the Grand Final.[http://www.fullpointsfooty.net/West_Torrens.htm]</ref> |- | Wally Cook || [[Victorian Football Association]] || [[Camberwell Football Club|Camberwell]] || [[Sandringham Football Club|Sandringham]] || [[1952 VFA season|1952]] ||76–75||<ref>Cook was awarded a free kick after an errant kick by Sandringham full-back went out of bounds without being touched. Siren went while he prepared to kick. A 60-yard torpedo snuck through to give Camberwell victory. {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article23190395 |title=GOAL AFTER BELL BEATS ZEBRAS. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=5 May 1952 |accessdate=10 May 2014 |page=10 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> |- | George Atkinson || [[West Australian Football League]] || [[Perth Football Club|Perth]] || [[Swan Districts Football Club|Swan Districts]] || 1952 || 62–59 ||<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/59547959 Marked the ball from 20 yard outs, goaled as the siren sounded]</ref> |- | Brian Rickards || VFL Reserves || [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] || [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] || 1954 ||101–99||<ref>Melbourne came back from over 30 points down in the last quarter to win the second semi final. Rickards took a mark about 50 yards out and on a difficult angle just before the siren sounded. In a swirling wind, he kicked a "perfect drop kick" to send the Demons' reserves through to the grand final. {{cite news|title=Demons Win With Goal After Siren|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/205395287|accessdate=17 May 2016|work=The Age|date=13 September 1954}}</ref> |- | Ian Fulwood || [[Port Lincoln Football League]] || Waybacks || Tasman || 1954 || 66–60 ||<ref>Semi-final. With scores level, Fulwood received a free kick close to goal after being pushed. The siren sounded as he received the ball, and Fulwood goaled to win the game. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/97180133]</ref> |- | [[Darrel Baldock]] || [[North West Football Union]] || [[East Devonport Football Club|East Devonport]] || [[Devonport Football Club|Devonport]] || 1955 ||58–55||<ref>Controversial finish as Baldock goaled after the siren. He'd been awarded a mark by Umpire C Crowe, although ball was in air when siren sounded. Strong wind blowing across ground prevented umpire from hearing it until after his decision was made. ''The Advocate'', 16 May 1955</ref> |- | Alex Andjelkovic || [[Victorian Football Association]] (Division 2) || [[Geelong West Football Club|Geelong West]] || [[Caulfield Football Club|Caulfield]] || [[1972 VFA season|1972]] ||120–115||<ref>Second semi-final. Andjelkovic, who had come on in the final quarter as the 17th man, marked 25–35 yards from goal with seconds remaining; he stubbed the ground while kicking, but the kick just went through for a goal; it was Geelong West's 21st consecutive win, as part of a [[perfect season]], and qualified it for the Grand Final.{{cite news|newspaper=Geelong Advertiser|publication-place=Geelong, VIC|title=West sneaks into final|page=12|date=28 August 1972}}</ref> |- | [[Kerry Good]] || [[List of Australian Football League night premiers|Night Series]] || [[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]] || [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] || 1980 || 57–54 ||<ref>Siren sounded before Good marked the ball but as the umpire hadn't signaled the end of the game Good was allowed to take his kick [http://www.australianrules.com.au/2005stories/top10night.html Australianrules.com]</ref> |- | Ian Milne || [[Great Southern Football League (South Australia)|Great Southern Football League]] || Goolwa || [[Yankalilla Football Club|Yankalilla]] || 1980 || 85–81 ||<ref>Despite being on a "very sharp angle", Milne was able to score the winning goal after the siren, helping Mount Compass to a four-point victory. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/186922174]</ref> |- | Mark Trueack || [[Great Southern Football League (South Australia)|Great Southern Football League]] || [[Mount Compass Football Club|Mount Compass]] || [[Myponga-Sellicks Football Club|Myponga]] || 1980 || 40–34 ||<ref>With scores tied, Trueack marked directly in front of goal as the siren sounded and converted the winning goal. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/187075364]</ref> |- | Mark Davis || [[Great Southern Football League (South Australia)|Great Southern Football League]] || Victor Harbor || Langhorne Creek || 1986 || 107–104 ||<ref>Marked from thirty metres out just as the siren sounded and kicked the winning goal. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/185639330]</ref> |- | Mick Cleeland || [[Picola & District Football League]] || [[Waaia Football Club|Waaia]] || [[Blighty Football Club|Blighty]] || 1990 || 114–113 ||<ref>Grand Final. Cleeland was given a free kick on the wing, and Blighty conceded a 50-metre penalty for throwing the ball away. The siren sounded, and the end of play was signalled by the umpire, after the 50-metre penalty was awarded but before it was measured out. The Blighty players believed they had won and began celebrating, but the 50-metre penalty was measured out and Cleeland goaled from 50m out to win the premiership for Waaia. Blighty lodged an official protest, but it was dismissed. [http://www.sportingpulse.com/club_info.cgi?c=1-6191-80854-251072-18611298&sID=93644]</ref> |- | [[Jack Aziz]] || [[Victorian Football Association]] || [[Werribee Football Club|Werribee]] || [[Springvale Football Club|Springvale]] || 1993 || 98–95 ||<ref>Preliminary final match. Aziz marked the ball after a quick Werribee clearance following a previous Werribee goal. He was able to kick the winning goal from 50 metres out, with the siren sounding while the ball was in flight. Werribee proceeded to the Grand Final, which they won.</ref> |- | Lindsay Dean || [[West Kimberley Football Association]] || Towns || Broome Saints || 2002 || 56–54 ||<ref>Marked the ball after a string of Towns passes and kicked a goal after the final siren, winning the Grand Final for Towns and denying Broome Saints their first premiership since 1979. [http://wkfl.asn.au/2002.html] [http://www.australianrulesfootball.com.au/pages/WestKimberleyFL]</ref> |- | Simphiwe Mbhalo || [[Australian Football International Cup]] || [[South Africa national with seconds remaining, missed to right hand side.</ref> |}
==Miscellaneous== There have been some cases of a kick after the siren which cannot be properly classified into one of the above tables due to extraordinary circumstances surrounding the outcomes of the games.
{| class="wikitable" width80% |- style="background:#87cefa;" ! !! Player !! Competition !! Team !! Opponent !! Year !! Score !! Outcome !! Details |- |1|| Considine ||[[Victorian Football League|VFA]] || {{AFL Nor}} || {{AFL Foo}} || [[1920 VFA season|1920]] || 51–56<br>(''No result'') || No kick || North Melbourne trailed 51–56 in the semi-final, and Considine had a shot after the bell from 30yds out. Fans stormed onto the field, and prevented Considine from taking his kick. The players eventually left the field, the match was declared a ''no result'' and a replay was held the next week.<ref name="sfabandon">{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|date=27 September 1920|title=Football incident – when is time up?|page=6|publication-place=Melbourne}}</ref> |- |2|| David Collins ||[[Tasmanian State Premiership]] || [[North Hobart Football Club|North Hobart (TANFL)]] || [[Wynyard Football Club|Wynyard (NWFU)]]|| 1967 || 91–92<br>(''No result'') || No kick || North Hobart trailed 91–92, and Collins had a shot after the siren from 20m out. Home-team Wynyard fans stormed onto the field, and prevented Collins from taking his kick right up until the Wynyard fans had taken down the goalposts, making a set shot impossible. Collins never got to take his kick, the match was declared a ''no result'' and the 1967 state premiership was withheld. For more details, see ''[[1967 Tasmanian State Premiership Final]]''. |- |3||[[Steven Baker (Australian footballer)|Steven Baker]]|| [[Australian Football League|AFL]] || [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] || [[Fremantle Football Club|Fremantle]] || 2006 || 94–94<br>''amended to''<br>93–94<br>(''Fremantle win'') || Behind, but withdrawn on review || In a passage of play that occurred after the siren sounded inaudibly, Baker scored a behind to tie the game, and received an illegal bump. He elected to cancel the behind and take a set-shot, which (with the umpires having now heard the siren) was a true after-the-siren kick. He scored another behind, drawing the scores level 94–94. However, four days later, Fremantle successfully challenged to have the result of the game amended to 94–93, reflecting the scoreline when the siren originally sounded. This decision cancelled Baker's kick. For more details see [[AFL siren controversy|''AFL siren controversy'']]. |- |}

revision.text:
{{citation style|date=March 2018}} '''Maya Ballgame''', which is a branch of the [[Mesoamerican Ballgame]], is an sport event that was played throughout the [[Maya civilization]]. The Maya civilization was spread out throughout much of Central America. One of the common links of the Mayan culture of Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and Belize is the game played with a rubber ball, about which we have learned from several sources.<ref>Blumchen.</ref> Maya ballgame was played with big stone courts. The ball court itself was a focal point of Maya cities and symbolized the city’s wealth and power. The playing arena was in the shape of an I with high platforms on either side of the court allowing for large numbers of spectators. Portable stone court markers known as ''hacha'' usually depicting animals or skulls were placed around the [[arena]].<ref>Palmer</ref> The game was played for 2 weeks.
==History== [[Image:Uaxactunballcourt.jpg|thumb|left|Ballcourt at [[Uaxactun]], in the [[Petén Basin]] region of the Maya lowlands]]
The Maya ball game originated more than 3,000 years ago.<ref>Blumchen.</ref> The [[Popol Vuh]] describes the history of the [[K'iche' people]] and their rulers and mentions the important position of the Maya ballgame. Through this ball game, a conflict of the forces of darkness and light is described and enacted. By tradition, the twin brothers, [[Hun Hunaphu]] and [[Vucub Hunaphu|Xbalanque]], used their time on earth to play ball. Through the noise of the game, the anger of [[Xibelba|Vucub Came]], the master of the underworld, was aroused. A fight ensued, from which resulted in the formation of the MBG. After the game, one of the brothers was decapitated and his head was used as the game ball. From the decapitated trunk of the player, blood escaped in the form of snakes. This blood was taken as a [[symbol]] of [[fertility]]. This scene is depicted in reliefs on the walls of MBG courts, such as the most famous example in [[Chichen Itza]] in [[Mexico]].<ref>Blumchen.</ref>
==Archaeological Sites and Finds== In the highlands of [[Chiapas]] and of [[Guatemala]] alone, 300 MBG courts have been found. Of these, 85% have been dated in the [[post-classic period]].<ref>Blumchen</ref> Only two early classic courts have been reported and these are at [[Palenque]] and [[Copan]].<ref>Scarborough</ref>
=== Inscriptios=== Murals depicting captives, warriors, Creation myths, and transfers of political power from one ruler to another were painted around the ball court.<ref>Palmer</ref>
===Public Structure=== The ballcourt in [[Cerros]] is contemporary and date to the [[Tulix ceramic phase]](100BC-100AD).<ref>Scarborough</ref> Both are similar in date to the other major public structures. Both courts at Cerros are oriented N-S and orient to the N-S medial axis of a pyramid.<ref>Scarborough</ref> They are also oriented with the W axis of another pyramid, and its associated plaza, appears to interesect the medial axis of the site of the site at a point approximately equidistant from either court.<ref>Scarborough</ref>
== Religious Aspects== The Maya ballgame was more than just an athletic event. It was also a sacrificial and religious event. The Maya believed that it was necessary to play the game for their own survival. The ballgame provided an opportunity to show devoutness to the gods by sacrificing captured kings and high lords, or the losing opponents of the game.<ref>Palmer</ref>
===Sacrifice and Decapitation=== [[Thirteen Rabbit]]'s ritual sacrifice shows death by decapitation and disembowelment.<ref>Vilcox</ref> Looking at sculptural portrayals this was most likely the standard technique used at [[El Tajin]]. As trophy heads were popular in Mayan Culture, it follows that they were important in ballgame.<ref>Vilcox</ref> Some death heads occurred as figurines; so sacred were the small sculptures that they were preserved and appear as offerings at non-elite burials in Late Classic domestic interments.<ref>Vilcox</ref> As stated earlier, decapitation was used as sacrifice at El Tajin. By looking at sculptures at other ballcourts decapitation was also used at [[Aparicio]], [[Veracruz]], and Chichen Itza, [[Yucatan]].<ref>Vilcox</ref> Severing of the head is also seen in the Popol Vuh. Some sources say the winning team's captain was decapitated, and at Chichen ìtza you can barely see that a squash and a couple of snakes representing Kuklkan popped out of the sacrificed captains head. This was an honor and the captain would have to accept a drink or food item.<ref>Vilcox</ref>
==Game-Play== [[Image:Chichén Itzá Goal.jpg|thumb|right|250px|'''Ballcourt goal''', [[Chichén Itzá]] ]]
The rules seem to have changed over the centuries. Certainly two teams played against each other. The number of players varied between 2 and 6 players per team. Sometimes, an additional person is seen in the illustrations, who is believed to be a referee. The ball was put in motion by action of the right hip, the right elbow and the right knee and was not permitted to touch the ground. It could be passed from person to person in each team by propulsion by one of the above body parts. The aim was to move the ball back to the opposite team, preferably through the ring. The goal of the opposition (what today might be termed ‘the defense’) was to force the offense to lose control and to allow the ball to touch the ground. The stone ring was an innovation of the late-classic and early post-classic periods, as seen in Chichen Itza and in [[Uxmal]]. Playing the ball off the border wall could intensify the game. The [[ricochet]] of the ball could hardly be anticipated, especially if the walls were uneven.<ref>Blumchen</ref>
===Equipment=== A rubber ball was always used. Its size and weight varied over the centuries. Most historians assume a weight of 3–4 kg and a size of a [[skittle ball]]. The existence of a [[caoutchouc tree]] was necessary to produce the ball. These trees were found in the tropical regions in the Maya territories.<ref>Blumchen</ref>
===Dress=== The usual dress for MBG players is known from iconographic and figural findings. These show leather protection mainly at the hips and the chest, but sometimes also at the knees and the arms, though very seldom at the feet. The clothing was used to protect against the impact of the ball. The protected parts of the body were used to strike the ball. Some players would wear [[head dresses]] (like deer heads) for [[ritual]] reasons.<ref>Blumchen</ref>
==Physical Aspects of the Ballgame== Variations in the MBG occurred over the centuries as they have in modern ball games over years of use. Despite the variations, it would appear that the physical loads of MBG were most similar to those of soccer-tennis.<ref>Blumchen</ref> Most likely the players of ballgame manifested a [[heart rate]] and [[blood pressure]] responses consistent with physical loads of light/moderate intensity, in the range of 4.5–5.5 [[Metabolic equivalent|MET]]s. Thus, the cardiovascular demands of popular sports seem to have remained relatively similar through several millennia.<ref>Blumchen</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maya Ballgame}} [[Category:Ancient sports]] [[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Mesoamerican sports]] [[Category:Indigenous sports and games of the Americas]] [[Category:Sacrifice]] [[Category:15th-century BC establishments]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{more citations needed|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Metro Gallery | fullname = Metro Gallery Football Club | image = Dreams_Metro_Gallery_FC_logo.png | image_size = 200px | nickname = | founded = {{Start date and age|2008}}, as Fourway Athletics | ground = [[Po Kong Village Road Park]] | capacity = 1,000 | chrtitle = Chairman | chairman = | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = | league = [[Hong Kong First Division League|Hong Kong First Division]] | season = [[2017–18 Hong Kong First Division League|2017–18]] | position = 12th | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_so1 = | leftarm1 = 143c8d | body1 = 143c8d | rightarm1 = 143c8d | shorts1 = ffffff | socks1 = 0b1752 | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_so2 = | leftarm2 = ffffff | body2 = ffffff | rightarm2 = ffffff | shorts2 = 000000 | socks2 = ffffff | website = https://www.facebook.com/MetroGalleryFC/ | current = }} '''Metro Gallery Football Club''' ({{zh|t=駿其足球會}}), currently known as '''HONGDA''' for sponsorship reasons, are a Hong Kong [[Association football|football]] club which currently competes in the [[Hong Kong First Division League|Hong Kong First Division]].
The club plays most of its home matches at [[Po Kong Village Road Park]].
==History== The team began as '''Fourway Athletics''' ({{zh|t=四海體育會}}), it joined [[Hong Kong First Division League|Hong Kong First Division]] in [[2008-09 in Hong Kong football|2008–09 season]] as a competition member ({{zh|t=競賽會員}}, members who pay a specific amount of money and sponsor a domestic cup of Hong Kong to [[the Hong Kong Football Association]], to join the Hong Kong First Division League) of [[the Hong Kong Football Association]].
In [[2009-10 in Hong Kong football|2009–10 season]], Fourway merged with [[Hong Kong Rangers FC|Rangers]] in the [[Hong Kong Second Division League|Hong Kong Second Division]] and was renamed as Fourway Rangers ({{zh|t=四海流浪}}) for the new season.
In [[2011–12 Hong Kong First Division League|2011–12 season]], the team was renamed Biu Chun Rangers in deference to club sponsor ''Biu Chun Watches''.<ref>{{zh-hk icon}} [https://archive.is/20120721074948/http://news.sina.com.hk/news/22/1/1/2419886/1.html 流浪盼足總分擔頻道製作費] Ming Pao. (By Sina.com.hk) 28 August 2011.</ref>
In [[2012–13 Hong Kong First Division League|2012–13 season]], the team was renamed as '''Yokohama FC Hong Kong''' as [[J. League Division 2]] team [[Yokohama F.C.]] purchased the [[Hong Kong Football Association]] membership of the team.
In the [[2013-14 Hong Kong First Division League|2013–14 season]], Yokohama FC Hong Kong moved their home ground from [[Siu Sai Wan Sports Ground]] to [[Tseung Kwan O Sports Ground]], finishing a disappointing 10th in the league.
For the [[2014–15 Hong Kong Premier League|2014–15]] season, the club attained sponsorship from ''Modic Entertainment'' and was thus renamed as '''YFCMD''' (''Yokohama FC Modic''). The team also once again moved stadiums to [[Sham Shui Po Sports Ground]].
In summer 2015, Modic Entertainment confirmed they will not extend the sponsorship contract with the club. Metro Gallery confirmed that they will attain the sponsorship.<ref>[http://offside.hk/news/yfcmd-change-name-to-dream-metro-gallery-fc "YFCMD change name to Dreams Metro Gallery FC"] offside.hk. Retrieved on 2015-07-20</ref> The team was then renamed as '''Dreams Metro Gallery FC'''.
On 6 July 2016, the club announced via Facebook that they would not field a team in the [[2016–17 Hong Kong Premier League|2016–17 season]], instead, choosing to voluntarily drop down to the First Division.<ref>{{zh-hk icon}} [https://www.facebook.com/DreamsMetroGalleryFC/videos/1644977935821207/ "夢想駿其來季動向事宜"]</ref> The [[South China Morning Post]] reported that the team was facing financial difficulties after failing to attain sponsorship for the Premier League.<ref>[http://www.scmp.com/sport/hong-kong/article/1985766/special-treatment-guangzhou-rf-will-get-players-concessions-if-they "Special treatment: Guangzhou R&F will get players’ concessions if they compete in Hong Kong Premier League"]</ref>

revision.comment: Kick scooters date back to the early 1900s; Ouboter presented the Kickboard "very successfully"? (weasel words); "huge success"? (so...this was a triumph?) This article needs a NPOV rewrite.
revision.text:
{{Advert|date=November 2018}}{{Infobox company | name = Micro Mobility Systems | logo = Micro Mobility Logo.jpg | caption = | native_name = <!-- Company's name in home country language --> | native_name_lang = de | type = [[Gesellschaftsrecht der Vereinigten Staaten#Corporation|Corporation]] | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = Sportsgoods, Toys, Electric Vehicles | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1999 | founder = Wim Ouboter | defunct = | location_city = Küsnacht, Switzerland | location_country = | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices &c. --> | area_served = | key_people = Wim Ouboter | products = | services = | revenue = 60 Mil. [[CH-Franken|CHF]] <small>([[Geschäftsjahr|GJ]] 2014)</small> <ref>http://www.sonntagszeitung.ch/read/sz_06_09_2015/wirtschaft/Die-Rueckkehr-der-Knutschkugel-42448</ref> | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = 57 <ref>http://www.ey.com/CH/de/Newsroom/News-releases/EY-Medienmitteilung-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-2015-Finalisten</ref> <small>(September 2015)</small> | homepage = [http://www.micro.ms/] }}
'''Micro Mobility Systems Ltd''', known as '''Micro''', is a company in Switzerland dedicated to invent urban mobility solutions like the [[kickscooter]] or the Microlino, an electric car, which was first presented at the [[Geneva Motor Show]] in 2016. In the United States, Micro's products are sold under the brand "Micro Kickboard" for [[trademark]] reasons. The company holds several patents for its products.<ref>{{citation | url = http://www.kickboardusa.com/blog/about-us/ | publisher = Kickboard USA | title = About Us | date = 2011-06-10}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Idea === Wim Ouboter, born in 1960 invented the [[Kick scooter|kickscooter]] out of laziness. He states, that the way from his apartement to his favorite restaurant was too far to go by foot and yet too close to use a bike. He then invented a foldable, two-wheeled Scooter for those kind of distances that could easily be folded anytime and placed in a backpack. He pitched his idea to Smart and they were willing to put one Scooter in every single car. Ouboter then tried to find a manufacturer for his innovation, but soon realized that Europe simply was too expensive. In Taiwan he could convince the owner of a factory to produce the Scooter, also because he had proof that Smart liked his idea. Just before the production could start Smart failed the [[moose test]] and so the project was put on hold, since Smart had to solve that problem.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.schweizerversicherung.ch/de/artikelanzeige/artikelanzeige_print.asp?pkBerichtNr=27883|title = Verlagsgruppe Handelszeitung|website = www.schweizerversicherung.ch|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref>
=== Formation of Micro Mobility Systems === But Ouboter had another idea: a three-wheeled Scooter, called the Kickboard. He teamed up with [[K2 Sports|K2]] and presented his idea at the International Sports Fair (ISPO) in Munich in 1998 very successfully. With the earned money he founded Micro Mobility Systems in 1999 and started producing the two-wheeled Scooter, which was an even bigger success. Because of the excessive demand, he allowed his partner in Taiwan to distribute the Scooter in the United States with the name [[Razor (scooter)|Razor]] for a commission. After having sold about one million Scooters in 2000, the sales decreased rapidly in 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://archiv.rhein-zeitung.de/on/01/06/29/magazin/news/lifboom.html|title = RZ-Online: Der Tretroller ist den Kinderschuhen entwachsen|website = archiv.rhein-zeitung.de|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/039978ae-0d3e-11e0-82ff-00144feabdc0.html#axzz42t3ax48S|title = Scooter pioneer that survived to ride again|last = Simonian|first = Haig|date = 2010-12-21|newspaper = Financial Times|issn = 0307-1766|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref>
=== Becoming a lifestyle brand === In the subsequent years, the company continued to invent new products, designed for urban mobility, like the Mini Micro for kids, the Scooter Luggage or the electric emicro one. In addition, Micro has teamed up with other brands, like Peugeot, Suitsupply or Vibram to name a few. Many celebrities and their kids, like David Beckham and his children, Alessandra Ambrosio or Hugh Jackman have been spotted riding a micro scooter.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.micro.ms/blog/view/24596|title = Micro Scooter Worldwide - Headoffice blog/view|website = www.micro.ms|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.microscooters.com.au/blog/2015/12/david-bekhams-london-sunset-scooting|title = David Beckham's London sunset scooting adventure at micro Scooters Australia|website = www.microscooters.com.au|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref>
With Micro Xtreme the brand also went into Freestyle Sports and works closely with professional Athletes like Benjamin Friant. After the huge success in 2000 and the rapid downfall in 2001, Micro has grown organically with a gross revenue in 2014 of 60 Million Swiss Francs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sonntagszeitung.ch/read/sz_06_09_2015/wirtschaft/Die-Rueckkehr-der-Knutschkugel-42448|title = Die Rückkehr der Knutschkugel|website = www.sonntagszeitung.ch|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref> With the development of the company, manufacturing capacities shifted to [[RazorUSA]] in [[California]]. The evolution of Micro into a lifestyle brand that invents mobility solutions for children, teenagers and adults was honoured by Ernest and Young in 2015, when Wim Ouboter was nominated as Entrepreneur of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ey.com/CH/de/Newsroom/News-releases/EY-Medienmitteilung-Entrepreneur-Of-The-Year-2015-Finalisten|title = EY - Medienmitteilung Entrepreneur Of The Year™ 2015: Finalisten stehen fest|website = www.ey.com|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref>
=== Microlino === [[File:Microlino Red Genf 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Microlino at Geneva Motor Show 2016]] The Microlino was first presented in 2016 at the Geneva Car Show. Based on the design of the [[Isetta]], a 1950s [[bubble car]] which was sold over 160,000 vehicles, the new design has a battery powered electric motor. The two-seat small car is designed for urban mobility with a top speed of {{convert|90|km/h|mph}}, a range of {{convert|120|km|mi}} and can be charged from a domestic power outlet. The car is expected to be on the market by the end of 2018 with an estimated price of 12,000 Euro and initial sales limited to Germany and Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sonntagszeitung.ch/read/sz_06_09_2015/wirtschaft/Die-Rueckkehr-der-Knutschkugel-42448%20http://www.wired.com/2016/03/microlino-modern-bmw-isetta/|title = Sonntagszeitung|website = www.sonntagszeitung.ch|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.wired.com/2016/03/microlino-modern-bmw-isetta/|title = Steve Urkel’s Isetta Finds Second Life as a Teensy Electric Car|website = WIRED|language = en-US|access-date = 2016-04-13}}</ref>. The company claims to have pre-orders for 8,000 vehicles as of September 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=8000 Reservations|url=https://www.micro-mobility.com/en/news/8000-reservations|website=Micro Mobility Systems|accessdate=2 November 2018|date=September 14, 2018}}</ref>

Case Study, University of St. Gallen, St. Gallen.] 2003 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120320000400/http://osdir.com/ml/culture.bicycle.birdybike.general/2000-05/msg00015.html culture.bicycle.birdybike.general: Folding Scooter Story - msg#00015 - OSDir] 2000

{{NFL Labor Relations}} The '''NFL lockout''' may refer to any of the [[Lockout (industry)|lockouts]] or [[Strike action|strikes]] in the history of the [[National Football League]]: * The '''[[1968 NFL strike/lockout]]''', which lasted 12 days before the start of the [[1968 NFL season|1968 season]]. * The '''[[1970 NFL strike/lockout]]''', which lasted a few days in July 1970. * The '''[[1974 NFL strike]]''', which lasted for two months before the start of the [[1974 NFL season|1974 season]]. * The '''[[1982 NFL strike]]''', which lasted for three months and eight weeks, forced the [[1982 NFL season|1982 season]] to be shortened to 9 games per team. * The '''[[1987 NFL strike]]''', which lasted for 24 days and forced the [[1987 NFL season|1987 season]] to be shortened to 15 games per team. * The '''[[2001 NFL referee lockout]]''', which lasted until September 19 and an agreement was reached to end the 2 week [[Lockout (industry)|lockout]]. * The '''[[2011 NFL lockout]]''', which lasted for over five months, resulted in cancellation of [[Pro Football Hall of Fame Game]] between the [[Chicago Bears]] and [[St. Louis Rams]], but preserved the [[2011 NFL season|2011 regular season]]. * The '''[[2012 NFL referee lockout]]''', which impacted the first few weeks of the [[2012 NFL season]].
==See also== *[[MLB lockout]] *[[MLS lockout]] *[[NBA lockout]] *[[NHL lockout]]
{{NFL}} {{Sport index}}
[[Category:National Football League|Lockout]] [[Category:Sports labor disputes in the United States]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox tennis biography | name = Nasser Ghanim Al-Khelaïfi | image = Nasser_Al-Khelaifi.jpg | caption = | country = {{Flagu|Qatar}} | residence = France, Qatar | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1973|11|12}} | birth_place = [[Doha]], [[Qatar]] | height = 1.78 m | turnedpro = 1992 | retired = 2004 | plays = Right handed | singlesrecord = 12–33 (at [[ATP Tour]] level, [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] level, and in [[Davis Cup]]) | singlestitles = 0 | highestsinglesranking = No. 995 (4 November 2002) | currentsinglesranking = | AustralianOpenresult = | FrenchOpenresult = | Wimbledonresult = | USOpenresult = | doublesrecord = 12–18 (at ATP Tour level, Grand Slam level, and in Davis Cup) | doublestitles = 0 | highestdoublesranking = No. 1040 (8 February 1993) | AustralianOpenDoublesresult = | FrenchOpenDoublesresult = | WimbledonDoublesresult = | USOpenDoublesresult = | updated = 20 May 2013 }}
'''Nasser bin Ghanim Al-Khelaïfi''' ({{lang-ar|ناصر بن غانم الخليفي}}; born 12 November 1973) is a Qatari [[businessman]] and is the chairman of [[beIN Media Group]],<ref name="beinsportsfrance">{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/mr-yousef-al-obaidly-appointed-president-of-bein-sports-france-260845751.html|title=Mr. Yousef Al-Obaidly Appointed President of beIN SPORTS France|author=beIN SPORTS France|date=27 May 2014|work=prnewswire.com}}</ref> chairman of [[Oryx Qatar Sports Investments|Qatar Sports Investments]],<ref name="qsi.com.qa">{{cite web|url=http://www.qsi.com.qa/who-we-are/|title=Who we are|work=qsi.com.qa}}</ref> president of [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] (PSG), and [[Qatar Tennis Federation]] (QTF) and vice president of the [[Asian Tennis Federation]] for West Asia (ATF).<ref>{{cite web|work=qatartennis.org|publisher=[[Qatar Tennis Federation]] (QTF)|title=About Us|url=http://qatartennis.org/about-us.html|accessdate=1 December 2011}} {{en icon}}</ref>
Al-Khelaïfi is chairman and chief executive officer of [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain Football Club]] in France. He is also a member of the organizing committee for the FIFA Club World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/organisation/bodies/standingcommittees/committee=1882024.html|title=FIFA.com - Organising Committee for the FIFA Club World Cup|work=FIFA.com}}</ref>
In 2015, he was crowned 'favourite Ligue 1 president' and in 2016, ''[[L'Equipe]]'' named him 'the most powerful man in French football'.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Al-Khelaïfi : "J'ai beaucoup appris au contact des autres présidents de L1"|url = http://www.francefootball.fr/news/al-khelaa-fi-a-j-ai-beaucoup-appris-au-contact-des-autres-pra-sidents-de-l1a/617754|website = France Football|access-date = 23 February 2016|language = fr-FR}}</ref>
==beIN Media Group== On 31 December 2013, Al Jazeera Sport global operations were spun off from [[Al Jazeera Media Network]] and rebranded as [[beIN Sports]]. In parallel, [[BeIN Media Group]] was incorporated and became the official owner of beIN Sports. Nasser Al-Khelaïfi was then appointed chairman and chief executive officer of beIN Media Group.<ref name="beinsportsfrance"/> beIN Sports has 22 channels including 17 HD channels and broadcasts across the Middle East, North Africa, Europe, North America, Australia and Asia. The strategy, aside from building the beIN premium sports network, is to develop the group's ambitions in sports and entertainment in production, distribution and digital media sectors.
==Qatar Sports Investments== Nasser Al-Khelaïfi has been chairman of Qatar Sports Investments (QSi) since June 2011. QSi is a fund dedicated to investments in the sport and leisure industry on a national and international level.<ref name="qsi.com.qa"/>
Following the QSi acquisition of Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) Football Club in June 2011,<ref>{{cite news|title=Qatari group takes control of Paris Saint-Germain|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/924844}}</ref> Nasser Al-Khelaifi became the chairman of the board of PSG and also CEO of the club,<ref name="psg.fr">{{cite web|url=http://www.psg.fr/en/Club/609001/Presidents|title=Presidents - club_presidents - PSG.fr|work=psg.fr}}</ref> reinforcing Qatari interest in French football.
QSi has several other high profile partnerships. They also used to sponsor Spanish football club [[FC Barcelona]]. QSi also owns the [[Burrda (brand)|Burrda]] sportswear brand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qsi.com.qa/portfolio/investments/|title=Portfolio|work=qsi.com.qa}}</ref>
===Paris Saint-Germain===
Nasser Al-Khelaïfi became the new chairman and chief executive officer of Paris Saint-Germain in October 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jean-Claude Blanc Directeur Général Délégué|url=http://www.psg.fr/fr/Article/003001/Article/55345/Jean-Claude-Blanc-Directeur-General-Delegue|date=7 October 2011}}</ref> Shortly after being named chairman he presented a five-year plan to take Paris Saint-German to the top of the tree in France and abroad.<ref>{{cite news|title=PSG: 'We want the new Messi'|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/psg-we-want-the-new-messi.htm|work =[[Ligue 1]]|date=1 July 2011|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> As part of the long term plan for the club, Al-Khelaïfi brought in legendary footballer [[Leonardo Araújo|Leonardo]] as the new director of football.<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://www.psg.fr/fr/Club/609001/Presidents PSG.FR : Liste des présidents] {{fr icon}}</ref>
Although Al-Khelaïfi had initially demanded a major trophy haul for the 2011-2012 season, PSG were soon eliminated from the [[Europa League]] and both domestic cups, leaving the team only able to compete $130 million on players, PSG failed to dominate, and lost out to eventual winners [[Montpellier HSC]], though they did qualify for the UEFA Champions League by finishing second.<ref>{{cite news|title=PS aiming to bounce back after French Club failure|url=http://www.supersport.com/football/france/news/140414/PSG_aim_to_bounce_back}}</ref>
In the [[2012-13 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. Season|2012-13 season]], PSG won the [[2012-13 Ligue 1|Ligue 1 title]] and also made it to the [[2012-13 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League]], thanks partly to the goalscoring of newly signed striker, [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]]. They eventually lost in a two-legged tie to [[FC Barcelona]] on away goals.
In the [[2013–14 Paris Saint-Germain F.C. season|2013–14 season]] PSG again finished top of [[2013-14 Ligue 1|Ligue 1]] with a record total of 89 points.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/psg-foot-paris-saint-germain/les-records-du-psg-cette-saison-19-05-2014-3854175.php#xtref=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.co.uk%2F|title=Les records du PSG cette saison|date=19 May 2014|work=leparisien.fr}}</ref> They reached the [[2013-14 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League]] where they lost to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] 3-3 on aggregate, again going out only on the away goals rule.
In June 2012, QSi acquired the Paris Handball Club and merged it with the PSG sport franchise to create a wider and more competitive sport offer to the city of Paris.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.20minutes.fr/sport/946487-20120604-apres-psg-qatar-sport-investments-devient-proprietaire-paris-handball|title=Après le PSG, Qatar Sport Investments devient propriétaire du Paris Handball|work=20minutes.fr}}</ref>
==Tennis== As a tennis professional, Al-Khelaïfi was the second most successful member of the [[Qatar Davis Cup team]] after [[Sultan Khalfan]], playing 43 ties between 1992 and 2002 and compiling a 12–31 record in singles, 12–16 in doubles. Al-Khelaïfi appeared twice on the [[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP) main tour, losing each time in his first round matches in [[Hypo Group Tennis International|St. Pölten]] in 1996 (where he lost to former French Open Champion [[Thomas Muster]]) and in [[Qatar Open (tennis)|Doha]] in 2001. He reached a career-high singles ranking of No. 995 in late 2002.<ref>{{cite web|work=atpworldtour.com|publisher=ATP Tour, Inc.|title=atpworldtour.com Profile|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/Tennis/Players/Al/N/Nasser-Ghanim-Al-Khulaifi.aspx|accessdate=1 December 2011}} {{en icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work=itftennis.com|publisher=ITF Licensing (UK) Ltd.|title=itftennis.com Men's Circuit record|url=http://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/players/player/profile.aspx?playerid=10006160|accessdate=1 December 2011}} {{en icon}}</ref>
Nasser Al-Khelaïfi has been president of the Qatar Tennis Federation since November 2008. In 2011, he was elected vice-president of the [[Asian Tennis Federation]] for West Asia. Nasser Al-Khelaïfi is a former Davis Cup player and member of the Qatar National Tennis Team with which he won the GCC Team Tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qatartennis.org/sections/index/14/board-of-directors.html|title=Qatar Tennis Federation - QTF - Qatar Tennis Tournaments and Championships|work=qatartennis.org}}</ref>
==Government of Qatar== In November 2013, Nasser Al-Khelaïfi was made Minister without Portfolio in the Qatari government by the emir of Qatar, [[Sheikh Tamim]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football365.fr/etranger/autres-championnats/nasser-al-khelaifi-nomme-ministre-au-qatar-1082524.shtml|title=Nasser Al-Khelaïfi nommé ministre au Qatar|publisher=www.football365.fr|language=French|date=2 December 2013|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Al-Khelaïfi was born in [[Doha]], and graduated from [[Qatar University]]. He is close to the Emir, Sheikh Tamim, head of sovereign wealth fund Qatar Investment Authority.
In February 2012, he won a French 'Sport Business' award, receiving the most votes out of 1,500 and finishing ahead of nine people.<ref>[http://www.psg.fr/en/article/003001/article/56883/Al-Khelaifi-receives-Sport-Business-award PSG.FR : Al-Khelaïfi receives Sport Business award]</ref>
His growing influence in the sport was recognised in 2015 when he was crowned 'favourite Ligue 1 president in a poll conducted by France Football, with 35% of the votes cast. In 2016, the French daily sport [[newspaper]] [[L'Équipe]] named him the 'most powerful man in French football' in a 30-man list, ahead of such notable individuals as [[Didier Deschamps]] and [[Zinedine Zidane]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Nasser Al Khelaifi {{!}} Le top 30 du foot français - L'ÉQUIPE.FR|url = https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/top30-classement-foot-francais-2015/1/nasser-al-khelaifi|website = lequipe.fr|access-date = 23 February 2016|language = fr-FR}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

(€12 million euros, excluding tax) | architect = [[Jean-Michel Lamaison]], [[Michel Camborde]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Élan Béarnais Pau-Orthez]] ([[basketball]]) | seating_capacity = 7,707 ([[basketball]]) | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} The '''Palais des Sports de Pau''' is an [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] that is located in [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]], [[France]]. The seating capacity of the arena for [[basketball]] games is 7,707 people, and the arena also includes a 500 capacity in private lodge areas. ==History== Palais des Sports de Pau has been used as the home arena of the [[Élan Béarnais Pau-Orthez]] French professional basketball team, since it opened in 1991. It has also frequently hosted games of the senior men's [[French national basketball team]]. It is the largest basketball-specific arena in France. ==External links== * [http://www.elan-bearnais.fr/club/psp.htm L'Histoire du Palais de Sports] {{coord|43|20|4|N|0|21|45|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in France]] [[Category:Basketball venues in France]] [[Category:Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques]] [[Category:Sports venues in Pyrénées-Atlantiques]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1991]] {{France-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Peace Bridge Arena''' was the main sports [[arena]] located in [[Fort Erie, Ontario]]. Built in 1928, it held 5,000 people. It was located near the [[Peace Bridge]] connecting Fort Erie with Buffalo, New York. Both the [[Chicago Blackhawks|Chicago Black Hawks]] and [[Pittsburgh Pirates (NHL)|Pittsburgh Pirates]] made the arena a temporary home for the first few games during the [[1928–29 NHL season]].
The arena was also the home of the [[Buffalo Bisons (IHL)|Buffalo Bisons]] ice hockey team; for a brief period in 1931, it also served as the backup arena for their crosstown rivals, the [[Buffalo Majors]], who normally played at [[Buffalo Broadway Auditorium]]. On March 17, 1936, the roof collapsed after thirteen inches of heavy snowfall, which ensured the original hockey Bisons' demise.
Eventually, in 1940, [[Buffalo Memorial Auditorium]], on the American side of the border, would open, replacing both Broadway Auditorium and Peace Bridge Arena; with it, a new [[Buffalo Bisons (AHL)|Bisons]] team would be established.
==External links== * [http://www.bisonshistory.com/peace-bridge.htm Peace Bridge Arena information]

52,000 (1982–2000)
30,000 (1963–1981) |}} The '''Sun Bowl''' is an outdoor [[American football|football]] [[stadium]] in the [[Southwestern United States|southwestern]] [[United States]], on the campus of the [[University of Texas at El Paso]]. It is home to the [[UTEP Miners football|UTEP Miners]] of [[Conference USA]], and the late December [[college football]] [[bowl game]], the [[Sun Bowl]]. The stadium opened {{Years or months ago|1963}} in [[1963 college football season|1963]] and has a current [[seating capacity]] of 51,500. ==History== The stadium, named for the game it hosts, was opened in September [[1963 Sun Bowl|1963]] with a [[UTEP Miners football|Texas Western]] win over [[North Texas Mean Green football|North Texas State]]. The opening play was a 54-yard touchdown run by Larry Durham of the Miners. The land on which the stadium sits was originally donated by the university to [[El Paso County, Texas|El Paso County]], who built the stadium for the school and the [[Sun Bowl]] game. Both had previously used {{nowrap|[[Kidd Field]],}} the school's current [[track and field]] venue, which seats 15,000. The city had realized that the game could not expand its audience or the list of teams that it could invite without a bigger stadium, so the Sun Bowl was built in a natural bowl adjacent to the west. It originally sat 30,000, with only the sideline grandstands. The playing field runs nearly north–south (tilted about {{nowrap|10° NW–SE)}} at an [[elevation]] of {{convert|3910|ft|round=5}} above [[sea level]]. ===Renovations=== The current press box was added in [[1969 Sun Bowl|1969]], and the stadium reached the capacity of 52,000 in [[1982 Sun Bowl|1982]] with the addition of the north end zone stands and the expansion of the east stands. (The south end zone is still vacant, with the ground of the bowl covered with the school's logos.) The school retook control of the land and stadium in [[2001 UTEP Miners football team|2001]], when hundreds of seats were removed as part of a re-configuration of the seating bowl to accommodate [[Association football|soccer]], which lowered capacity to its current figure of 51,500. The school's Athletics Director, [[Jim Senter (athletic director)|Jim Senter]], announced on April 13, 2018 plans to renovate the Sun Bowl Stadium. The $15 million dollar project would include luxury boxes installed in a new press facility, renovation of the concourses and premium seating added on the west side of the stadium. The renovations are projected to be completed in a 16-month timespan. ==Notable events== ===Postseason college football=== ====Sun Bowl==== {{main|Sun Bowl}} The college football bowl game began {{Years or months ago|1936}} in January [[1936 Sun Bowl|1936]] and moved to the new stadium in December [[1963 Sun Bowl|1963]]. All games have been played in El Paso. ====All-star game==== On February 2, 2007, the stadium hosted the inaugural [[Texas vs The Nation|Texas vs. The Nation all-star college football game]]; the Nation defeated Texas {{nowrap|24–20.{{cite news |title=Team Nation victorious |author=Matthew Aguilar |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4T0X-4900-TXCN-M0BR&csi=257494&oc=00240&perma=true |work=[[El Paso Times]]|accessdate=August 24, 2017}}}} ===Concerts=== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2018}} The Sun Bowl is also a venue for music and other large public events, having hosted concerts by [[U2]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Pink Floyd]], and [[Kenny Chesney]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Date ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Artist/Group ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Opening act(s) ! width=12% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Tour / Concert name ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Attendance ! width=10% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Revenue ($) ! width=5% style="text-align:center;{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UTEP Miners|color=#FFFFFF}};"| Notes |- | align=right|October 27, 1992 || [[U2]] || [[The Sugarcubes]]
[[Public Enemy (group)|Public Enemy]] || [[Zoo TV Tour]] || 35,564 / 39,500 || 1,066,920 || |- | align=right|April 26, 1994 || [[Pink Floyd]] || — || [[The Division Bell Tour]] || 34,945 / 37,000 || 1,148,228 || |- | align=right|August 27, 2001 || [[NSYNC]] || Li'l Johnnie
[[Deborah Gibson]] || [[PopOdyssey]] || 38,313 / 48,987 || 2,048,331 || |- | align=right|October 20, 2006 || [[The Rolling Stones]] || [[Dave Matthews Band]] || [[A Bigger Bang (concert tour)|A Bigger Bang]] || 38,653 / 38,653 || 3,106,995 || |- | align=right|{{nowrap|September 19, 2014}} || [[One Direction]] || [[5 Seconds of Summer]] || [[Where We Are Tour (One Direction)|Where We Are Tour]] || 44,910 / 44,910 || 3,632,097 || |- | align=right|September 6, 2017 || [[Guns N' Roses]] || [[ZZ Top]] || [[Not in This Lifetime... Tour]] || 34,801 / 41,534 || 3,112,504 || |} ===Other events=== On February 17, 2016, the stadium hosted festivities and a simulcast of the Mass held by [[Pope Francis]] during the pontiff's visit to [[Ciudad Juarez]], Mexico, several miles away across the [[Rio Grande]].{{cite news|title=Pope Francis hosts papal mass 2Nations1Faith event|publisher=Fox7Austin.com|url=http://www.fox7austin.com/news/local-news/93058331-story|accessdate=August 24, 2017}} ==Other tenants== For a short time before moving to [[Dudley Field (El Paso)|Dudley Field]], it was the home to [[USL Premier Development League|PDL]] franchise, the [[El Paso Patriots]]. They now play at [[Patriot Stadium]]. ==Photos== image:SunBowl1.jpg|Sun Bowl Stadium view from Durham Center image:SunBowl3.jpg|Sun Bowl Stadium view from tunnel image:SunBowl4.jpg|View from within Sun Bowl Stadium Image:SunBowl2.jpg image:UTEPDurhamcenter.jpg|Sun Bowl Stadium view from northern entrance ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Sun Bowl Stadium}} *[http://utepathletics.cstv.com/facilities/sun-bowl.html UTEP Athletics] – Sun Bowl Stadium {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Sun Bowl]] | years = 1963–present | before = [[Kidd Field]] | after = Current }} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[UTEP Miners]] | years = 1963–present | before = [[Kidd Field]] | after = Current }} {{end}} {{UTEP Miners football navbox}}{{UTEP}} {{Conference USA football venue navbox}} {{Sun Bowl navbox}} {{NCAA Division I FBS bowl game stadium navbox}} {{Texas college football venues}} [[Category:Sun Bowl]] [[Category:NCAA bowl game venues]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Texas]] [[Category:UTEP Miners football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1963]] [[Category:Sports venues in El Paso, Texas]] [[Category:American football venues in Texas]] [[Category:1963 establishments in Texas]]

It is owned and operated by the [[Korçë |Municipality of Korçë]] and it is the home of the multidisciplinary [[KF Skënderbeu Korçë|KS Skënderbeu]]. {{infobox hockey team | team = Tartu Kalev-Välk | colour = black | colour text = yellow | logo = | logosize = 150px | city = [[Tartu]], [[Estonia]] | league = [[Meistriliiga (ice hockey)|Meistriliiga]] | conference = | division = | founded = {{Start date|1994}} | operated = | arena = [[Lõunakeskus]] | colours = {{Color box|black|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|yellow|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|blue|border=darkgray}} | owner = | GM = Oleg Litvjakov | coach = | captain = | affiliates = | parentclub = | farmclub = | website = {{URL|http://www.valk494.ee}} }} [[File:Unifrom Kalev-Valk.png|thumb|Uniform]] '''Kalev-Välk''' is an [[ice hockey]] team located in Tartu, Estonia, and playing in the [[Meistriliiga (ice hockey)|Meistriliiga]], the top tier of the Estonian hockey league system. Their home arena is in [[Lõunakeskus]], which has the capacity for up to 600 spectators.
Kalev-Välk is the current champion of [[2010–11 Meistriliiga season]] and [[2011–12 Meistriliiga season]].<ref name=medalikolmikud>{{cite web|title=Medalikolmikud|url=http://www.icehockey.ee/en/eesti-mv/statistika.html|publisher=Estonian Ice Hockey Association|accessdate=1 June 2011|language=Estonian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829160700/http://www.icehockey.ee/en/eesti-mv/statistika.html|archivedate=29 August 2011|df=}}</ref>
The team also participated to the [[2011–12 IIHF Continental Cup]], in [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]], and finished 2nd of the Group A.

[[Wealdstone F.C.]] (1991–1994)
[[Saracens F.C.]] (1997–2012) | dimensions = 120 x 80 [[yards]] (110 x 73 meters) | surface = [[Desso GrassMaster]] |}} '''Vicarage Road''', a stadium in [[Watford]], Hertfordshire, England, is the home of the [[association football|football]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] of the [[Premier League]]. An all-seater stadium, its current capacity is 23,700 following the completion of the new Sir Elton John Stand in 2014, and expansion work in 2015 and again throughout 2016 and 2017; this included expansion of the football pitch.[http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/watford_2293498_692872 Watford: Club info] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421020630/http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/watford_2293498_692872 |date=21 April 2012 }}. [[The Football League]]. 1 August 2010. Accessed 30 September 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/150608-vicarage-road-stadium-north-east-corner-2486084.aspx |title=Stadium Update: North-East Corner Transformation To Begin |publisher=Watford F.C. |date=9 June 2015 |accessdate=10 June 2015}} ==History== It has been the home of Watford since 1922, when the club moved from [[Cassio Road]].Trefor Jones (1996). ''The Watford Football Club Illustrated Who's Who.'' T.G. Jones. p. 9. {{ISBN|0-9527458-0-1}}. The ground was officially opened by Col. Charles Healey of [[Benskins Brewery]] for the visit of [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on 30 August 1922. In addition to being Watford's home since opening, the stadium was also home to [[Wealdstone F.C.]] between 1991 and 1993,[http://www.wealdstonefc.co.uk/page.php?history.htm Wealdstone Football Club history]. Wealdstone Football Club Supporters Club. Accessed 2 October 2011. and to [[rugby union]] side [[Saracens F.C.|Saracens]] from 1997 until they moved to their new home at [[Allianz Park]] in February 2013.Allnutt, Tom (22 January 2013). [http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/10176843.Saracens___Thank_you_Watford_FC_/ "Saracens: 'Thank you Watford FC'"]. ''Watford Observer''. Retrieved 25 January 2012. After purchasing the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] of the stadium from Benskins in January 2002, Watford's financial situation forced them to sell and lease back the stadium later that year.[[David Conn]] (21 September 2002). [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1712032.html New owners of Vicarage Road revealed as Watford wither]. ''[[The Independent]]''. Accessed 2 May 2014. However, after a campaign entitled 'Let's Buy Back The Vic' with donations coming from fans, as well as celebrity former owner [[Elton John]] donating the entire proceeds of a concert held at the venue, the club was able to repurchase the stadium in September 2004.[[Graham Simpson (businessman)|Graham Simpson]] (31 March 2005). [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:7wGg07yRZuMJ:www.watfordfc.com/staticFiles/13/7/0,,10400~1811,00.doc+Watford+buy+back+vicarage+road+site:watfordfc.com&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg11_FMZLJuNOapCZh8zMpuT5gRmuw-ZGB6HIMIMFpo0YzluzqXFuR2rfkciu7HawjCTAItRoqJo3D3_5I1Yo9xuhQSVM5swqxCH_2ujKZ-K2nFYY_VT-_OkXWBJU8pZlmLCxGI&sig=AHIEtbTpXSVL15ZcQJJIzWFq8JoILLW_1A Watford Leisure PLC: Interim Results for the six months ended 31 December 2004]. Watford Leisure PLC. Accessed 30 September 2011. On 1 September 2011 it hosted [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21s]] [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 8]] match against [[Azerbaijan national under-21 football team|Azerbaijan under-21s]]. The hosts thrashed the visitors 6 – 0 with braces from [[Craig Dawson]] and [[Henri Lansbury]] and single goals from [[Jordan Henderson]] and [[Martyn Waghorn]]. There were 7,738 in attendance. ==Vicarage Road Stand== [[File:Vicarageroad1.jpg|thumb|left|Rugby game at Vicarage Road, 2005]] The Vicarage Road Stand was built following the conclusion of the 1992–93 season. Previously an open terrace, the all-seater stand was built to comply with the [[Taylor Report]] and raise the standard of the ground. It cost £2.3 million to build and had a capacity of 5,800 people. Construction was largely funded by the £1.2m sale of [[Bruce Dyer]] in 1994.Trefor Jones (1996). ''The Watford Football Club Illustrated Who's Who.'' T.G. Jones. p. 75. {{ISBN|0-9527458-0-1}}. Originally a mere earth bank when the club moved to the ground, it was gradually transformed into a conventional terrace. In 1978, an electronic scoreboard was put up, which became an iconic symbol of Watford's eighties heyday. In a display of solidarity with the home support, [[Graham Taylor (footballer)|Graham Taylor]] maintained that the benches for the coaching staff and substitute on the side of the pitch would remain exposed to the elements until such time as the home end was covered. Its final game as a terrace was a 1–0 loss to [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] on 8 May 1993. It opened to the public once more on 18 September 1993, with Watford defeating [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] 3–1.{{cite web |url=http://www.wfc.net/stadium.htm|title=The Stadium|publisher=wfc.net|accessdate=3 May 2014}} Previously the home stand, it now houses the away support. A partition was subsequently added, meaning that both home and away support could be put in the stand. Half of the stand is given to away fans, and the other half is used as the family area for home fans. It also houses wheelchair supporters of both teams. Since August 2012, the stand has been home to the Hornets Shop{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/120810-hornets-shop-move-305371.aspx|title=RETAIL: New Home For The Hornets Shop|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=10 August 2012|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503045413/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/120810-hornets-shop-move-305371.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} ==The Rookery Stand== [[File:Rookery, Vicarage Road.jpg|thumb|alt=Part of a stadium, consisting of yellow and red seats. A grass football pitch is visible to the left.|The Rookery Stand]] The Rookery Stand was built over the course of the [[1994-95 in English football|1994–95 season]]. Another former terrace, the all-seater Rookery stand has a capacity of 6,960. Larger than the Vicarage Road stand, it has facilities on two levels and also holds most of the club's administrative areas. The stand cost £1.6 million to build, approximately £300,000 of this figure was contributed by the Football Trust, with the remaining money coming from the £2.3m sale of [[Paul Furlong]] by then-owner [[Jack Petchey]] in 1994.[http://www.harrowtimes.co.uk/news/295444.the_details_are_petchey/ The details are Petchey]. ''Harrow Times''. 7 May 2003. Accessed 2 October 2011.Trefor Jones (1996). ''The Watford Football Club Illustrated Who's Who.'' T.G. Jones. p. 91. {{ISBN|0-9527458-0-1}}. When Watford moved from Cassio Road, this end of the ground featured a roof over a cinder bank, and over the years the roof eventually had to be removed for safety reasons. The Supporters' Club eventually raised funds to enable the Rookery End to feature concrete terracing under cover, and this aim was realised in 1959. The new stand, replacing the 1959 model was used by Watford supporters for the first time on 22 April 1995, for the visit of [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]]. As part of redevelopment work in conjunction with the Watford Health Campus, 164 units of affordable housing, known locally as ''The Wrap'', were built on and around the Rookery end. Construction finished in 2009.Alex Hill (4 November 2009). [http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/news/4720611.Mayor_Wraps_up_football_club_housing/ Mayor Dorothy Thornhill Wraps up Vicarage Road housing]. ''[[Watford Observer]]''. Accessed 2 October 2011. The Rookery is the "home end". It lends its name to the Watford fans' podcast, ''From The Rookery End''.[http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/9171001.Cherished_memories_for_Hornets_fans/ Watford fans podcast "From the Rookery End" call for supporters' memories]. ''Watford Observer''. 1 August 2011. Accessed 1 October 2011. The stand was known as the ''Rover South'' for Saracens matches.{{cite web |url=http://www.saracens.com/news/view.php?Id=4271|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403000600/http://www.saracens.com/news/view.php?Id=4271|archivedate=3 April 2012|title=Changes to the South West turnstiles|publisher=[[Saracens F.C.|Saracens]]|date=10 January 2008|accessdate=2 May 2014}} ==The Graham Taylor Stand== [[File:Vicarage Road Rous and SW Corner 2012.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A two-tiered seating area featuring red, yellow and black seats, running along the length of a football pitch.|The Graham Taylor Stand and incomplete south west corner (left), pictured in 2012.]] The Graham Taylor Stand was renamed for the 2014–15 season, taking its name from the club's most successful manager [[Graham Taylor (footballer)|Graham Taylor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-graham-taylor-stand-1520316.aspx|title=GRAHAM TAYLOR OBE: Hornets To Honour Former Manager With Stand Re-Naming|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=1 May 2014|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503044213/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-graham-taylor-stand-1520316.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} It was previously named after former [[FIFA]] president Sir [[Stanley Rous]]. The official renaming ceremony took place on 29 November 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/watford-fc-graham-taylor-stand-gallery-2111076.aspx|title=GALLERY: Graham Taylor Stand First Look|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=28 November 2014|accessdate=29 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141201051251/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/watford-fc-graham-taylor-stand-gallery-2111076.aspx|archivedate=1 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} The stand with its distinctive wavy roof runs along the side of the pitch, on the west side of the ground. It is a two-tiered stand, with executive boxes and a TV camera gantry. Built in 1986, it replaced the Shrodells Stand. The £3 million development was partly funded via a loan from [[Elton John]]. The upper tier, complete with executive boxes, was constructed first, and temporary seats forming a lower-tier were added later. These were later replaced with permanent seats, first used for a game against [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] on 18 September 1993. When the club moved from [[Cassio Road]] in 1922, the Union Stand was transported and reconstructed on this side of the ground. It was replaced by the Shrodells Stand, which was constructed during the 1930s. It was extended in 1979 with a further 2,200 seats replacing the standing enclosure in front of the stand. The final match for the Shrodells Stand was a 1–1 draw against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 3 May 1986, the Graham Taylor Stand opened on 23 August 1986, when Oxford United visited Vicarage Road, with Watford coming out 3–0 winners. ==The Sir Elton John Stand== [[File:Main Stand.jpg|thumb|The now demolished Main Stand]] The Sir Elton John Stand sits on the east side of the ground, and contains the changing rooms & tunnel. The stand was fully opened on 13 December 2014, in a ceremony attended by [[Sir Elton John]].{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/141213-gallery-watford-fc-v-wigan-elton-john-2145481.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020005/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/141213-gallery-watford-fc-v-wigan-elton-john-2145481.aspx |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy }} Prior to the development of the Sir Elton John Stand, the east side of the ground was home to the Main Stand, which was constructed in 1922 following Watford FC's move from Cassio Road. The Main Stand was closed in 2008 due to safety concerns.{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordfc.com/page/Stadium/0,,10400~2069271,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512044614/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/Stadium/0,,10400~2069271,00.html|archivedate=12 May 2012|title=East stand changes|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=14 June 2010|accessdate=2 May 2014}} Following the acquisition of Watford FC by the Pozzo family in 2012, the club were able to finance the development of a new stand to replace the Main Stand. The redevelopment of the east side of the stadium began in 2013, with the aim of developing a 3,000 seater capacity stand which would also house the players changing rooms, television gantry and tunnel.[http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/130923-east-stand-contract-1071880.aspx "East Stand IS Happening"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926210503/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/130923-east-stand-contract-1071880.aspx |date=26 September 2013 }}. Watford Football Club. 23 September 2013. Accessed 24 September 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/10811108.East_Stand_images_released/|title=See a number of artist's impressions of Watford's new East Stand here|first=Frank|last=Smith|publisher=''Watford Observer''|date=15 November 2013|accessdate=3 May 2014}} In May 2014, it was announced the stand will be known as The Watford FC Community Stand. However the club announced in November 2014 that the new stand would instead be named after former chairman Sir Elton John.{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-watford-fc-community-stand-1521713.aspx|title=Name Confirmed: The Watford FC Community Stand|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=1 May 2014|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503090301/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-watford-fc-community-stand-1521713.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} The changing rooms were used for the first time in a friendly match between Watford and Udinese on 2 August 2014. On 8 June 2015, the club confirmed that 700 extra seats were being installed in the recently built Sir Elton John Stand. This number was revised a day later to around 1000 extra seats, following the announcement of an expansion in the north-east corner. ==Floodlights== The first game under [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlights]] at Vicarage Road was played in 1953, when lights were installed on top of the Main Stand. These were replaced in 1960, with four pylons being built in the corners of the ground. Currently the floodlights are mounted on the top of the Vicarage Road and Rookery Stands. New LED floodlights have been added for the 2015/16 season including lights on the top of the Sir Elton John and Graham Taylor stands. ==Railway stations== [[File:Croxley rail link stations old and new.png|thumb|The old and new stations on the Croxley Rail Link near Vicarage Road]] In 1982, Vicarage Road Stadium gained its own railway station, {{rws|Watford Stadium Halt}}. It was introduced as a means of [[crowd control|managing the crowds]] attending football matches, providing an alternative to {{rws|Watford High Street}} and {{rws|Watford Junction}}, and was only open on match days. Development of the station was funded jointly by the [[Football Trust]], [[Watford Borough Council]], Watford F.C. and [[British Rail]]. The station was officially opened on 4 December 1982 by Elton John and [[Morys Bruce, 4th Baron Aberdare|Lord Aberdare]], chairman of the Football Trust. The inaugural train rolled into the station five minutes late, bringing away fans of [[Manchester United]] to Vicarage Road; the match that day ended with a 1–0 defeat for Watford.{{cite news|last=Crozier|first=David|title=Elton rides in to open soccer halt|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/nostalgia/memories/10593045.Elton_rides_in_to_open_soccer_halt/|accessdate=12 August 2013|newspaper=Watford Observer|date=11 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812123903/http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/nostalgia/memories/10593045.Elton_rides_in_to_open_soccer_halt/|archive-date=12 August 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The station fell out of use when [[British Rail]] closed the railway line in 1996 and has remained derelict ever since. A new [[London Underground]] station, {{LUL stations |station=Watford Vicarage Road}}, is due to open in 2020 on the opposite side of the Vicarage Road bridge as part of the [[Croxley Rail Link]] project to extend the [[Metropolitan line]] to [[Watford Junction railway station|Watford Junction]].{{cite web|title=Croxley Rail Link|url=http://www.croxleyraillink.com/|accessdate=11 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101102174226/http://www.croxleyraillink.com/|archive-date=2 November 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} However since March 2017 the project has been in doubt due to a significant shortfall in funding.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/transport/metropolitan-line-extension-to-watford-junction-could-be-axed-due-to-funding-gap-a3490276.html|title=Metropolitan line extension could be axed due to £50m funding gap|date=2017-03-15|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en-GB}} == Greyhound racing == Greyhound racing initially began at Vicarage Road on 20 October 1928. The racing was held under [[National Greyhound Racing Club]] (NGRC) rules and as many as four race nights per week were held every Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 7.45pm. However the provisional NGRC licence was cancelled as early as 1 November 1928, forcing the track to race independently (unaffiliated to a governing body).{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Encyclopedia of Greyhound Racing|year=1981|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=07207-1106-1}} The racing would continue for many years alongside the football team and was still active for the next forty years before a temporary closure on 28 June 1969. On 14 October 1974 racing returned under NGRC rules under the organisation of the industry’s leading promoter the [[Greyhound Racing Association]]. Derby winning trainer Barbara Tompkins was attached to the track and won the Buckinghamshire Cup at [[Slough Stadium]] in 1975 with Houghton Girl.{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=NGRC book of Greyhound Racing|year=1990|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=0-7207-1804-X}} The shape of track was very sharp due to the nature of the bend design around the football pitch corners and this led to criticism within the industry that it was not safe enough. Despite this a Bookmakers Afternoon Greyhound Service (BAGS) contract was established at the track. During 1977 the club announced plans to end the greyhound racing so that stadium improvements could go ahead.{{cite web|url=http://greyhoundstar.co.uk/remember-november-3/|title=Greyhound Star (Remember When November 1977)|publisher=Greyhound Star}} The final race meeting took place on 30 October 1978. The last winner was a greyhound called Chad Supreme.{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}} ==References== ;General * Phillips, Oliver (1991). ''The Official Centenary History of Watford FC 1881–1991.'' [[Watford Football Club]]. {{ISBN|0-9509601-6-0}}. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140503044757/http://www.watfordfc.com/documents/2013-14-visiting-the-vic286-1100924.pdf#page=5 Vicarage Road stadium layout]. Watford Football Club. Accessed 2 May 2014. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120531071914/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/History/0,,10400~65929,00.html Ground changes]. Watford Football Club. Accessed 2 October 2011. ;Specific {{Reflist|30em}} {{Watford F.C.}} {{Football League Championship Venues}} {{Premier League venues}} {{Watford}} {{2000 RLWC Venues}} {{English greyhound tracks}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Watford]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in England]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hertfordshire]] [[Category:Watford F.C.]] [[Category:Premier League venues]] [[Category:Defunct rugby league venues in England]] [[Category:Rugby League World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1922]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in London]] [[Category:Greyhound racing in London]]

{{About||the arena of this name in [[Des Moines, Iowa]]|Wells Fargo Arena (Des Moines)|the arena in Philadelphia formerly known as Wachovia Center|Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)}} {{Coord|33.424524|N|111.930948|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Wells Fargo Arena | nickname = | image = Wellsfargo.jpg | image_size = 250px | location = 600 E Veterans Way
[[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]], [[Arizona|AZ]] 85287 | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1972 | built = | opened = April 29, 1974 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Arizona State University | operator = | construction_cost = $8 million
{{small|(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|8000000|1972}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})}} | architect = Drover, Welch & Lindlan, Inc.{{cite web |title=ASU Tempe Campus Buildings Survey, 1960-2007|url=http://lib.asu.edu/sites/default/files/archives/BuildingData.pdf|publisher=Arizona State University|accessdate=November 6, 2013}} | general_contractor = Olson Construction Company | former_names = ASU Activity Center {{small|(1974–97)}} | tenants = [[Arizona State Sun Devils]] {{small|([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1974–present)}} | capacity = 14,100 }} '''Wells Fargo Arena''' (formerly '''ASU Activity Center''') is a 14,000-seat{{cite news |title=ASU Reduces Capacity at Wells Fargo Arena|first=Doug|last=Haller|url=http://www.azcentral.com/sports/asu/articles/2010/12/04/20101204asu-basketball-reduce-wells-fargo-arena-capacity.html|newspaper=[[The Arizona Republic]]|location=Phoenix|date=December 4, 2010|accessdate=December 15, 2010}} multi-purpose [[arena]] located at 600 E Veterans Way in [[Tempe, Arizona]], a suburb of [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]. Constructed in the spring of 1974 as the ASU Activity Center and at the cost of $8 million, it is the home of multiple [[Arizona State University]] athletic teams, to include [[Arizona State Sun Devils men's basketball|men's basketball]], women's basketball, women's volleyball, women's gymnastics, and men's wrestling. The facility also plays host to graduation ceremonies and a variety of concerts and shows. The building replaced [[Sun Devil Gym]] as the primary arena for the Sun Devils' basketball team. Naming rights for the arena were purchased by [[Wells Fargo & Co.]] in 1997. ==Design== The structure is 403 feet long, 340 feet wide and six stories high. The structure contains offices and locker rooms for men's basketball, women's basketball, women's volleyball, and the men's and women's track and field team, along with a weight room, coaches and film rooms, and an equipment room. ==Events== [[Led Zeppelin]] played their third-to-last show as part of their [[Led Zeppelin North American Tour 1977|1977 North American Tour]] [[Bruce Springsteen]] & the [[E Street Band]] performed at the arena on November 5, 1980 during the [[The River Tour|River Tour]]. Video and audio of the show were released in 2015 in conjunction with the band's ''[[The River (Bruce Springsteen album)#The Ties That Bind: The River Collection|The Ties That Bind]]'' commemorative box set, and their performance of "[[Badlands (Bruce Springsteen song)|Badlands]]" was included on 1986's ''[[Live 1975–85]]'' album. The arena hosted the first dates of [[U2]]'s [[The Joshua Tree Tour|Joshua Tree Tour]] in March 1987, with the tour eventually concluding next door at [[Sun Devil Stadium]] in December of that year. It hosted the 1990 [[Pac-12 Conference|Pacific-10 Conference]] men's basketball tournament. Previously, the Sun Devils played at [[Sun Devil Gym]]. The arena has also hosted the 1st and 2nd rounds of the [[NCAA]] Women's Basketball Tournament in both [[2015 NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament|2015]] and [[2016 NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament|2016]]. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes==References== ==External links== {{Commons category|Wells Fargo Arena (Tempe)}} * [https://tours.asu.edu/tempe/wells-fargo-arena Wells Fargo Arena] on the ASU virtual tour {{ASU}} {{Arizona State Sun Devils men's basketball navbox}} {{Arizona State Sun Devils women's basketball navbox}} {{Pacific-12 Conference basketball venue navbox}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College gymnastics venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:Arizona State Sun Devils men's basketball]] [[Category:Arizona State Sun Devils women's basketball]] [[Category:Arizona State Sun Devils women's volleyball]] [[Category:Arizona State Sun Devils wrestling]] [[Category:Arizona State University buildings]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Arizona]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tempe, Arizona]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Arizona]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1974]] [[Category:Arizona State Sun Devils]]
